item.title: UK Visa Scams Squeeze Millions From Would-Be Care Workers
item.description: Recent changes to immigration policy won’t do anything for people who’ve been exploited while seeking jobs in the UK. But they may worsen the care-worker shortage.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Mr. Brown (left), a self-described “scammer hunter,” and his de facto bodyguard Sting.

item.title: Romania to Hold Rates With All Eyes on Leu Path
item.description: Romania’s central bank will probably keep interest rates unchanged on Friday, with investors looking for any clues about the outlook for the leu after political turmoil pushed the currency to record lows.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of Romania's central bank in Bucharest.

item.title: Trump to Keep 30% China Tariffs Till Late 2025, Analysts Say
item.description: Donald Trump’s tariffs on China will likely remain at a level expected to severely curtail Chinese exports to the US after the 90-day truce, analysts and investors say, suggesting Beijing may have to endure further economic pain despite active talks.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Li, Yujing Liu, Iris Ouyang

media:content.media:description: Packages at a neighborhood sorting center in Beijing, China, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Previously exempted from any levies under the so-called 'de minimis' rule, parcels shipped-from-China to US priced up to $800 now face an ad-valorem tax — of 120% of a product’s value — or a per postal item fee of at least $100 starting May 2.

item.title: Japan’s Economy Shrinks for First Time in a Year Before Tariff Jolt
item.description: Japan’s economy was shrinking even before the bulk of US President Donald Trump’s tariff measures took force, leaving the economy at risk of sliding into recession as Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba heads into an election and the central bank weighs policy.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Japan Aims for Currency Talks With US Based on Past Dialogue
item.description: Japanese Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato said he’ll seek another opportunity to talk with his US counterpart Scott Bessent next week to discuss currency matters, building on their dialogue last month.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Japanese 10,000 yen, left, and US 100 dollar banknotes arranged for a photograph in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, May 10, 2024. The Bank of Japan offered to purchase a smaller amount of government bonds in a regular operation on May 13 than it did on April 24 as it seeks to reduce its presence in the country’s debt market. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

item.title: Traders Dial Back Rate Cut Bets in Asia on Easing Trade Tensions
item.description: Markets are pricing in less aggressive policy easing by central banks in emerging Asia’s export-dependent economies, following signs of reduced trade frictions between the US and China.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong

item.title: Is the Age of American Exceptionalism Nearing an End?
item.description: Markets delivered a withering verdict on Donald Trump’s trade war last month. They also may have turbocharged the decline of US economic primacy.
item.dc:creator: David Rovella

item.title: World Economic Forum Courts Lagarde as Its Next Leader After Founder’s Abrupt Exit
item.description: Klaus Schwab’s abrupt departure from the World Economic Forum, the influential organization he founded and led for more than half a century, has complicated carefully laid plans to persuade Christine Lagarde to assume the helm in a seamless transition, according to people familiar with the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Hugo Miller, Jan-Henrik Foerster, Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde

item.title: Trade War Brings Ontario Budget Deficit to Near Pandemic Levels
item.description: Ontario’s budget shortfall is expected to reach its highest level since the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic as the effects of the trade war hurt economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Hughes

media:content.media:description: Doug Ford, Ontario's premier, arrives at the First Minister's Meeting at the Canadian War Museum in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, March 21, 2025. Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, is set to call a national election within days, seeking his own mandate from voters at a time when the country's businesses have been shaken by a trade war with the US.

item.title: Banxico Delivers Third Half-Point Cut as Growth Slows
item.description: Mexico’s central bank cut borrowing costs by half a percentage point Thursday after the economy narrowly avoided falling into recession and inflation remained within the target range.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: Mexico's central bank headquarters, the Banco de Mexico, in Mexico City, Mexico, on Tuesday, March 4, 2025. The Mexican peso slumped after US President Donald Trump imposed new import tariffs against the country, though other developing-nation currencies held their own amid concerns about the impact of the escalating trade war on growth in the world's largest economy.

item.title: Nigeria’s Inflation Eases, Boosting Case for Rate Pause
item.description: Nigeria’s annual inflation slowed in April, shrugging off the impact of a currency slump and increasing the chance of another rate pause next week.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo

media:content.media:description: Nigeria's consumer prices rose 23.7% last month from 24.2% in March.

item.title: Fed’s Barr Says Supply Chain Disruptions Could Boost Inflation
item.description: Federal Reserve Governor Michael Barr said the economy is on solid ground, but warned tariff-related supply-chain disruptions could lead to lower growth and higher inflation.
item.dc:creator: Reade Pickert

media:content.media:description: Michael Barr, vice chair for supervision at the US Federal Reserve, speaks during a Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 16, 2024. Martin Gruenberg, the embattled head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., told lawmakers calling for his resignation that he was moving quickly to overhaul the agency's workplace culture after a probe detailed complaints of sexual harassment and discrimination at the agency.

item.title: Colombian Economy Beats Forecasts With 2.7% Expansion
item.description: Colombia’s economy grew at the fastest pace in two years as record high coffee prices boosted the agricultural sector.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: A worker arranges Colombian flowers for export

item.title: US-China Trade Clash Risks Making Europe Dumping Ground for Cheap Goods
item.description: China’s widening trade surplus with the European Union is fueling fresh concerns that the 27-nation bloc risks becoming a dumping ground for cheap goods in the volatile tariff confrontation between Washington and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, William Horobin

item.title: Peru Economy Expanded 4.7% in March, Fastest Pace This Year
item.description: Peru’s economy posted its fastest growth of the year in March, the national statistics institute reported Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun

item.title: Four in Five Canadians Believe Old US Relationship Is ‘Over,’ Poll Says
item.description: An overwhelming majority of Canadians believe the country’s relationship with the US has permanently changed, as President Donald Trump’s tariffs and sovereignty threats spark widespread fury in the northern nation.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: A "Product of Canada" sign near packaged meats at a grocery store in Langford, British Columbia, Canada, on Wednesday, Feb. 26, 2025. Furious Canadian consumers are boycotting American-made products and opting for domestic alternatives in response to US President Donald Trump's threats and actions.

item.title: GOP Tax Bill Seen Masking More Than $1 Trillion US Debt Hit
item.description: The cost of Republican lawmakers’ draft plan for sweeping tax cuts weighed in at $3.8 trillion over the next 10 years in one official estimate, a lowball projection that independent analysts say masks the true fiscal hit.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran, Nancy Cook

item.title: US Homebuilder Sentiment Slides to Lowest Level Since 2023
item.description: Confidence among US homebuilders slumped in May to the lowest level since late 2023, as tariffs made it harder to price homes and anxious consumers dragged their feet on purchases.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

item.title: US Producer Prices Fell Unexpectedly in April as Margins Shrank
item.description: Prices paid to US producers unexpectedly declined in April by the most in five years, largely reflecting a slump in margins, suggesting companies are absorbing some of the hit from higher tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: A worker on the trim assembly line at the General Motors assembly plant in Fort Wayne, Indiana, US, on Tuesday, April 9, 2024. General Motors Co. is scheduled to release earnings figures on April 23. Photographer: Emily Elconin/Bloomberg

item.title: Powell Signals 2020 Fed Framework Language on Chopping Block
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said policymakers are weighing changes to key parts of the framework that guides their monetary policy decisions, including how they think about shortfalls in US employment and approach their inflation target.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell Photographer: Tierney L. Cross/Bloomberg

item.title: US Retail Sales Barely Rise, Suggesting Some Spending Pullback
item.description: Growth in US retail sales decelerated notably in April, reflecting consumers pulled back spending on cars, sporting goods and other categories of imported goods amid concerns about rising prices from tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

item.title: US Factory Output Declines for the First Time in Six Months
item.description: US factory production declined in April for the first time in six months, marking a soft start to the second quarter for manufacturers encumbered by higher import duties.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

item.title: Canadian Home-Price Declines Accelerate Amid US Trade Tensions
item.description: Canadian home prices fell the most in more than a year as buyers spooked by the US trade war stayed on the sidelines.
item.dc:creator: Ari Altstedter

media:content.media:description: Homes in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, May 9, 2025. The slump in Toronto home prices deepened in April as ongoing uncertainty over Canada's trade war with the US causes listings to pile up on the market.

item.title: Germany Expects €33.3 Billion Less in Taxes on Weak Economy
item.description: Germany’s federal government will reap €33.3 billion ($37.3 billion) less in tax income in the five years through 2029, as the economy’s persistently sluggish performance saps revenue.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Lars Klingbeil during a session at the Bundestag in Berlin, on May 15. Photographer: Tobias Schwarz/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: South African Deputy Finance Chief Sees Budget 3.0 as Done Deal
item.description: South Africa’s deputy finance minister said next week’s national budget is set to secure approval from lawmakers, after two previous iterations were scrapped because of disagreements within the governing coalition over taxes.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek, Robert Brand

media:content.media:description: David Masondo

item.title: New York Manufacturing Activity Contracts for a Third Month
item.description: New York state factory activity contracted in May for a third month while a gauge of prices paid for materials jumped to the highest level since July 2022, highlighting the impact of the Trump administration’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

media:content.media:description: A glassworks in Brooklyn, New York. Photographer: Stephanie Keith/Bloomberg

item.title: Extorsiones guerrilleras limitan el desarrollo agroindustrial en los llanos colombianos
item.description: Años después del acuerdo de paz, nuevas guerrillas extorsionan a productores de palma, arroz y petróleo en Colombia. “Sin seguridad, nadie invierte”, advierte un empresario.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Bristow

media:content.media:description: In this Feb. 13, 2015 photo, a truck loaded with crude from the Campo Rubiales oil field crosses the bridge over the Manacacias River in Puerto Gaitan, Colombia. A net oil importer not too long ago, Colombia is now the fifth biggest supplier to the U.S. (AP Photo/Fernando Vergara)

item.title: EU Deal Would Give Reeves £10 Billion and Cut Risk of Tax Hikes
item.description: An improved trade deal with the European Union would hand UK Chancellor Rachel Reeves £10 billion ($13.3 billion) in the Autumn Budget and limit the need for further tax increases, according to economists.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer, ahead of a news conference on the publication of the government's immigration white paper, in London, UK, on Monday, May 12, 2025. The UK will increase English-speaking requirements for migrants, and make it harder for them to stay in the country as part of efforts to rein in levels of net immigration that have touched records in recent years.

item.title: JPMorgan, Apollo Executives Say US Could Dodge a Recession
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co.’s chief of global markets strategy said the US could dodge a recession as the probability of that scenario has decreased following better clarity over global trade.
item.dc:creator: Meg Short, Jack Sidders

media:content.media:description: Dubravko Lakos-Bujas Photographer: Cyril Marcilhacy/Bloomberg
